title: Citation and Footnotes in quarto
text:
footnotes:

markdown footnote syntax (as I have to look this up regularly)

citations:

explain initial setup including a test
explain steps to generate citations and a bibliography with quarto

title: Citation and Footnotes in quarto
text:
3.1 input
Here is a footnote reference,[^1] and another.[^longnote]

[^1]: Here is the footnote.
[^longnote]: Here's one with multiple blocks.

    Subsequent paragraphs are indented to show that they
belong to the previous footnote.

        { some.code }

    The whole paragraph can be indented, or just the first
    line.  In this way, multi-paragraph footnotes work like
    multi-paragraph list items.

This paragraph won't be part of the note, because it
isn't indented.
Remark: The content of the footnote, e.g. [^1]: Here is the footnote. can be placed anywhere in the document. I usually put it at the end of the document, because some footnotes are used more than once.

title: Citation and Footnotes in quarto
text:
3.2 output
Here is a footnote reference,1 and another.2
This paragraph won’t be part of the note, because it isn’t indented.

title: Citation and Footnotes in quarto
text:
3.3 inline footnote
Here is an inline note.^[Inlines notes are easier to write,
since you don't have to pick an identifier and move down to
type the note.]
Here is an inline note.3

title: Citation and Footnotes in quarto
text:
5.1 Bibliography Generation
Supose you want to add a new reference to your citation database references.bib, e.g. (Trotta et al. 2022). I usually do the following:

open google scholar
search for your reference, e.g. “trotta routing on a ring”
use the nice link “citation” below the hit of google scholar and choose BibTex next
simply copy and paste the content to your references.bib file. The copied content will look like:

@article{trotta2022pickup,
  title={Pickup and delivery problems with autonomous vehicles on rings},
  author={Trotta, Manuel and Archetti, Claudia and Feillet, Dominique and Quilliot, Alain},
  journal={European Journal of Operational Research},
  volume={300},
  number={1},
  pages={221--236},
  year={2022},
  publisher={Elsevier}
}

title: Citation and Footnotes in quarto
section: 5.2 Add a citation in a blog document
text:
5.2 Add a citation in a blog document

Markdown format for citation is [@citation]
Given example: [@trotta2022pickup] renders to (Trotta et al. 2022)
There are other markdown format for citation, e.g. @trotta2022pickup renders to Trotta et al. (2022). For more information just have a look at the sources below.

title: blending 1
text:
We want to produce a predefined quantity of a product, e.g. steel. The produced product must have certain characteristics (grades) - see section below. In stock we have different possible ingredients, e.g. ores, and these ingredients contribute differently to the requirements and have different availablility and prices - see section below.
We want to determine the recipie which minimizes the production costs.
source: Guéret, Prins, and Sevaux (1999) p.62


Code
import pandas as pd
import pyomo.environ as pyo

title: blending 1
text:
sets

\(raw\) - set of raw materials
\(comp\) - set of grade requirements

title: blending 1
text:
variables

\(use_r\) - used quantity in optimal recipie of raw material \(r\)

title: blending 1
text:
parameter

\(demand\) - demand of the product
\(produce\) - produced quatity of the product
\(cost_r\) - costs of raw material \(r\)
\(P_{rc}\) - percentage of component \(c\) in raw material \(r\)
\(Pmin_c\) - minimal requirement of component \(c\) in product
\(Pmax_c\) - maximal requirement of component \(c\) in product

title: blending 1
text:
objective

find the recipe with minimal costs fulfilling the requirements

title: blending 1
text:
constraints

(c1) produced quatity is given by the sum of the used rat materials (in tons)
(c2) lower limit on the components in the final product
(c3) upper limit on the components in the final product
(c4) use only available quatities of the raw materials
(c5) produced quatity fulfills demands

title: blending 1
github actions
text:
GitHub Actions allows you to automate your build, test, and deployment pipeline by continuous integration and continuous delivery (CI/CD).
You can create workflows to build and test every pull request to your repository. Whenever an event occurs a workflow is triggered. A workflow contains one or more jobs. In other words: We specify in a workflow what (jobs) should be done when (event).
A workflow is stored as a YAML file in the .github/workflows directory.
In our case we had to modify a predefined workflow from nbdev, because we have to install some non python packages which require root write permissions.



We first give the content of the yaml-file and explain its parts afterwards.
name: stochprog_test
on: [push]

permissions: write-all

jobs:
  build:

    runs-on: ubuntu-20.04

    steps:
      - uses: actions/checkout@v3
      - name: Set up Python 3.8
        uses: actions/setup-python@v4
        with:
          python-version: '3.8'
      - name: install solver
        run : sudo apt-get install -y libopenmpi-dev glpk-utils
      - name: poetry install
        run: |
          python -m pip install --upgrade pip
          curl -sSL https://install.python-poetry.org | python3 -
          poetry install
      - uses: fastai/workflows/quarto-ghp@master
      - uses: fastai/workflows/nbdev-ci@master


First we specify the name of the workflow. The given name will be displayed in the action tab of your github repository.



Then we specify the events which will trigger the workflow. - for single event use on: push - for multiple events use on: [push, fork] - list of events that trigger workflows - there are many other activity types to trigger a workflow, e.g. issue creation



We can modify the permissions granted to the GITHUB_-_TOKEN. For simplicyty we did this for all scopes, but the permissions can be granted to to different scopes and specific jobs.



A workflow is made of one or more jobs which specify what has to be done. Here build is the name of the job, which is defined afterwards. In the build job we define 1. runs-on: ubuntu-20.04 specifies the type of machine the job runs on 1. steps list the tasks of the job - Each step runs in its own process in the runner environment and has access to the workspace and filesystem. Because steps run in their own process, changes to environment variables are not preserved between steps - uses: uses: fastai/workflows/quarto-ghp@master runs an action of the fastai public repository 1. As the virtual Linux machines run passwordless we can use sudo without providing a password but add option -y to confirm the installation. Put together: run : sudo apt-get install -y libopenmpi-dev glpk-utils





chaching dependencies to improve performance

title: Linear programming tricks
text:
2 Summary
In this post we saw a number of tricks to transform special models into a linear program and mentioned typical applications. We saw how to handle absolute values, minimax objectives, fractional objectives and range contraints.






References

Bisschop, Johannes. 2006. AIMMS Optimization Modeling. Lulu. com.

Footnotes


Tricks for integer programming models will be part of another blog post.↩︎

title: jupyter test
text:
import pyomo.environ as pyo


model = pyo.ConcreteModel()

model.x = pyo.Var([1,2], domain=pyo.NonNegativeReals)

model.OBJ = pyo.Objective(expr = 2*model.x[1] + 3*model.x[2])

model.Constraint1 = pyo.Constraint(expr = 3*model.x[1] + 4*model.x[2] >= 1)


solver = pyo.SolverFactory('glpk')


solver.solve(model)

{'Problem': [{'Name': 'unknown', 'Lower bound': 0.666666666666667, 'Upper bound': 0.666666666666667, 'Number of objectives': 1, 'Number of constraints': 2, 'Number of variables': 3, 'Number of nonzeros': 3, 'Sense': 'minimize'}], 'Solver': [{'Status': 'ok', 'Termination condition': 'optimal', 'Statistics': {'Branch and bound': {'Number of bounded subproblems': 0, 'Number of created subproblems': 0}}, 'Error rc': 0, 'Time': 0.01656818389892578}], 'Solution': [OrderedDict([('number of solutions', 0), ('number of solutions displayed', 0)])]}



model.pprint()

1 Set Declarations
    x_index : Size=1, Index=None, Ordered=Insertion
        Key  : Dimen : Domain : Size : Members
        None :     1 :    Any :    2 : {1, 2}

1 Var Declarations
    x : Size=2, Index=x_index
        Key : Lower : Value             : Upper : Fixed : Stale : Domain
          1 :     0 : 0.333333333333333 :  None : False : False : NonNegativeReals
          2 :     0 :               0.0 :  None : False : False : NonNegativeReals

1 Objective Declarations
    OBJ : Size=1, Index=None, Active=True
        Key  : Active : Sense    : Expression
        None :   True : minimize : 2*x[1] + 3*x[2]

1 Constraint Declarations
    Constraint1 : Size=1, Index=None, Active=True
        Key  : Lower : Body            : Upper : Active
        None :   1.0 : 3*x[1] + 4*x[2] :  +Inf :   True

4 Declarations: x_index x OBJ Constraint1

title: Welcome To My Blog
text:
Add some welcome text.

blog will be mainly about mathematical optimization
objects basic notions from stochastic programming (as short high level intro for colleagues with no optimization background)



Let summarize the steps to reproduce such a blog. This is mainly written for myself to avoid reading multiple

Create a github repo and clone it with SSH
Create conda env and add packages (we use solvers from conda forge)

conda create --name SP_blog python=3.8
conda install -c conda-forge poetry
poetry init
poetry add pandas jupyterlab pyomo
conda install -c conda-forge ipopt glpk coincbc

create quarto blog project

quarto create-project SP_blog --type website:blog

move content from created folder SP_blog to the root directory





modify quarto.yml

project:
  type: website
  output-dir: docs

add a .nojekyll to root of repository

touch .nojekyll

configure Github repo add picture


go settings
go pages
select publish from branch (suggested main) and docs directory deployment can take a while





for a new blog create a folder in the posts folder
create an index.qmd or index.ipynb file with blog content
inspect result with quarto preview
render, commit and push

quarto render
git status
git add .
git commit -m "commit message"
git push




https://quarto.org/docs/publishing/github-pages.html
https://quarto.org/docs/websites/website-blog.html
https://docs.github.com/en/authentication/connecting-to-github-with-ssh/generating-a-new-ssh-key-and-adding-it-to-the-ssh-agent

title: Change constraints with examples in pyomo
text:
In a stochastic program with chance constraints we make an optimal decision prior to the realization of random data while allowing constraints to be violated with a probability specified by us. Chance constraints are also called probabilistic constraints.
In this post we will give the general mathematical description for stochastic programs with chance constraints and explain the following types of change constraints in detail and give example implementations in pyomo:

single chance
joint chance constraints
individual chance constraints



Mathematically a stochastc program with chance constraints is expressed as follows:
\[
\begin{array}{cc}
\min_x & c\cdot x \\
s.t.   & P(Ax\leq b) \geq p\\
       & x\geq 0
\end{array}
\]
where the symbols are denoting: - \(x\in\mathbb{R}^n\) the decision variable, - \(c\in\mathbb{R}^n\) the coefficients in the objective function, - \(A\in\mathbb{R}^{m\times n}\) coefficient of the constraints, - \(b\in\mathbb{R}^m\) the right hand side of the constraints and - \(p\in(0,1]\) is the probability that the constraints (or some of them) may be violated.



To solve a stochastic program with change constraints we can convert it into a mixed-integer problem as follows:
Let \(S\) denote the set of scenarios and let \(y_k\) be a binary variable for each \(k\in S\), i.e. \(y_k\) equals 1 if and only if the constraint is satisfied in the corresponding scenario, then a scenario-based formulation of the above chance constrained stochastic program is given by:
\[
\begin{array}{cc}
\min & c x \\
s.t. & A_kx \leq b_k + M_k(1-y_k) \\
     & \sum_{k\in S} y_k \geq p\cdot |S| \\
     & x\geq0\\
     & y\in \{0,1\}^{|S|}
\end{array}
\]
Here \(M_k\in\mathbb{R}^m\) is a suitable choosen big-M vector.




import pyomo.environ as pyo


I = [1,2]
S = [1,2,3,4]
Omega = {1:1, 2:2, 3:3, 4:4}
prob = {1:0.25, 2:0.25, 3:0.25, 4:0.25}
p = 0.75


def cc(p, I, S, prob, omega):
    ## sets
    m = pyo.ConcreteModel()
    m.I = pyo.Set(initialize = I)
    m.S = pyo.Set(initialize = S)
    
    ## parameter
    @m.Param(m.S)
    def omega(m,s):
        return Omega[s]
    
    @m.Param(m.S)
    def py(m,s):
        return prob[s]
    
    m.M = pyo.Param(initialize = 10)
    m.p = pyo.Param(initialize = 1-p, doc = 'risk tolerance')
    
    # vars
    m.x = pyo.Var(m.I, domain = pyo.NonNegativeReals)
    m.y = pyo.Var(m.S, domain = pyo.Binary)
    m.cc = pyo.Var(domain = pyo.NonNegativeReals, bounds = (0, m.p))
    
    # objective
    m.OBJ = pyo.Objective(expr = sum(m.x[i] for i in m.I), sense = pyo.minimize)
    
    # constraints
    @m.Constraint(m.S)
    def c1(m, s):
        return m.omega[s] * m.x[1] + m.x[2] >= 7 + m.M * (1 - m.y[s])
    
    m.cc_def = pyo.Constraint(expr = m.cc == 1 - sum(m.py[k] * m.y[k] for k in m.S))
    
    solver = pyo.SolverFactory('glpk')
    solver.solve(m)
    
    return m


m = cc(p, I,S,prob,Omega)
m.pprint()

2 Set Declarations
    I : Size=1, Index=None, Ordered=Insertion
        Key  : Dimen : Domain : Size : Members
        None :     1 :    Any :    2 : {1, 2}
    S : Size=1, Index=None, Ordered=Insertion
        Key  : Dimen : Domain : Size : Members
        None :     1 :    Any :    4 : {1, 2, 3, 4}

4 Param Declarations
    M : Size=1, Index=None, Domain=Any, Default=None, Mutable=False
        Key  : Value
        None :    10
    omega : Size=4, Index=S, Domain=Any, Default=None, Mutable=False
        Key : Value
          1 :     1
          2 :     2
          3 :     3
          4 :     4
    p : risk tolerance
        Size=1, Index=None, Domain=Any, Default=None, Mutable=False
        Key  : Value
        None :  0.25
    py : Size=4, Index=S, Domain=Any, Default=None, Mutable=False
        Key : Value
          1 :  0.25
          2 :  0.25
          3 :  0.25
          4 :  0.25

3 Var Declarations
    cc : Size=1, Index=None
        Key  : Lower : Value : Upper : Fixed : Stale : Domain
        None :     0 :  0.25 :  0.25 : False : False : NonNegativeReals
    x : Size=2, Index=I
        Key : Lower : Value : Upper : Fixed : Stale : Domain
          1 :     0 :   7.0 :  None : False : False : NonNegativeReals
          2 :     0 :   0.0 :  None : False : False : NonNegativeReals
    y : Size=4, Index=S
        Key : Lower : Value : Upper : Fixed : Stale : Domain
          1 :     0 :   1.0 :     1 : False : False : Binary
          2 :     0 :   1.0 :     1 : False : False : Binary
          3 :     0 :   1.0 :     1 : False : False : Binary
          4 :     0 :   0.0 :     1 : False : False : Binary

1 Objective Declarations
    OBJ : Size=1, Index=None, Active=True
        Key  : Active : Sense    : Expression
        None :   True : minimize : x[1] + x[2]

2 Constraint Declarations
    c1 : Size=4, Index=S, Active=True
        Key : Lower : Body                                : Upper : Active
          1 :  -Inf :   7 + 10*(1 - y[1]) - (x[1] + x[2]) :   0.0 :   True
          2 :  -Inf : 7 + 10*(1 - y[2]) - (2*x[1] + x[2]) :   0.0 :   True
          3 :  -Inf : 7 + 10*(1 - y[3]) - (3*x[1] + x[2]) :   0.0 :   True
          4 :  -Inf : 7 + 10*(1 - y[4]) - (4*x[1] + x[2]) :   0.0 :   True
    cc_def : Size=1, Index=None, Active=True
        Key  : Lower : Body                                                       : Upper : Active
        None :   0.0 : cc - (1 - (0.25*y[1] + 0.25*y[2] + 0.25*y[3] + 0.25*y[4])) :   0.0 :   True

12 Declarations: I S omega py M p x y cc OBJ c1 cc_def

title: building blog
text:
Hamel Husain and Jeremy Howard did a great job with nbdev 2
often their post start with migration from nbdev 1 or other topics
to shorten the reading of their posts I am sumarizing their post for myself here
there will be some gaps we have to fill which I did not saw while reading or were not mentioned by Hamel Husain and Jeremy Howard

title: building blog
text:
history

setup (nbdev project)

install quarto (one time)
create conda env + poetry
create empty repo and clone it
poetry init
poetry add nbdev notebook
nbdev_new
commit and push to test CI/CD workflows
set up github pages
nbdev_install_hooks
nbdev_export
pip install -e ‘.[dev]’

add dependencies to github workflow
unrelevant from nbdev bloging tutorial

   quarto create-project --type website:blog .
   quarto install extension quarto-ext/video

relevant from nbdev bloging tutorial

create blog directory in the nbs folder
create index.qmd file
edit _quarto.yml
quarto publish :

If using GitHub Pages, commit your files to GitHub before publish your site. No GitHub Actions are needed, you can use quarto publish instead. If you want to automate your workflow with GitHub Actions, you can follow these instructions.

title: About
text: At the moment its mainly about how to build a blog with nbdev and quarto and publish it on github. As the documentation for these three tools is exhaustive, the corresponding blog post aggregate what was relevant for myself.
